feed.title: Combined summary - Gossip Observer: New project to monitor the Lightning P2P network

entry.title: Combined summary - Gossip Observer: New project to monitor the Lightning P2P network
entry.summary: The project focused on the Lightning gossip network has provided significant insights since its inception, revealing key observations about message propagation dynamics. The initiative has effectively monitored the network by collecting gossip messages from a broad range of nodes, with crucial resources and findings available [here](https://www.example.com). One primary observation is the notable decrease in convergence delay for messages to spread across the network, improving from around 500 seconds to 200 seconds for 75% propagation. This improvement likely stems from Lightning Network (LN) implementations favoring more peer-to-peer connections by default. Additionally, it was found that a considerable portion of messages were received from less than a quarter of the observing node's peers, hinting at potential inefficiencies or selective filtering policies within LN implementations. Regarding message types, channel_update messages made up 60% of total message volume, with 20% of channels exceeding 144 messages. This data is crucial for evaluating proposed rate limits for Taproot gossip or gossip version 1.5. Furthermore, node_announcement messages, constituting 30% of all messages, had 2.5% of nodes announced over 144 times, indicating possible issues with specific implementations or automated tools. The overall size of unique messages collected surpassed expectations, emphasizing potential underestimations of node bandwidth usage due to receiving identical messages across multiple peers. Efforts are underway to expand the project by setting up permanent infrastructure to receive gossip from various geographic locations and P2P graph segments, enhancing the study of gossip message spread. The discussion also explores the transition of the LN's peer-to-peer (P2P) network towards a more efficient design, inspired by the Erlay paper and Bitcoin Improvement Proposal (BIP), potentially reducing latency and propagation delay. Given that gossip messages are publicly signed, eliminating the need for sender anonymity, this transition focuses on adopting Minisketch for LN gossip. This requires a mapping mechanism resistant to collisions while keeping data elements short. The Erlay-inspired approach suggests using unique salts combined with transaction identifiers (TXIDs) to create distinct Minisketch set elements via a fast hash function like SipHash. An alternative involving the channel's short ID and block height was considered less favorable due to low entropy issues. The proposed gossip 1.5 format could include optional fields in messages, allowing nodes to customize the information sent based on supported features, aiming to eliminate message flooding in favor of set reconciliation methods. This evolution seeks to simplify implementation and reduce bandwidth consumption but faces challenges such as disparate node filtering policies, which could lead to inefficiencies and failed reconciliations. Engaging with LN implementers on the feasibility of these changes is vital, as feedback will guide the development of a concrete proposal or draft BIP, marking a significant step towards improving LN's efficiency and scalability. In contrast to the Erlay design, there's an argument that LN might not require any message flooding, as combining limited flooding with set reconciliation can help reduce total propagation delay. However, Minisketch entails superlinear decoding costs, making frequent reconciliations potentially costly due to communication overheads. The use of iblt instead of Minisketch, possibly supplemented with a small Minisketch to resolve stuck IBLT decodes, is suggested as an alternative, despite higher overheads, if traffic runs entirely through it. This approach would leverage the strengths of both methods, balancing out the limitations inherent in each.
